div.head:
Epigramme 15. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Let the worke of the Potter, consisting in siccity and moisture,
instruct you.

lg.l: Water the Potter mixing with his clay,
Makes vessells Shapd by wheele without delay:
This cheifely dos his aime and art expresse,
The thirsty earth with liquor to refresh:
His road is safe, proceed, and doe not turne
Drowne not your earth, nor suffer it to burne.

div.head: Discourse 15.
div.ab:
As this orbe is by the connexion f earth and water conglobated into one
round body, soe allso the Potters worke seems to be compounded of the
same Elements particularly, namely of siccity and moisture, that one
may regulate the other: for if the earth should be without water, nei
ther the Ocean, sea, lakes, rivers, or fountains would be near the earth,
it could bear nothing of itselfe, but remaine barren: Soe if water should
not be received into the cavityes of the earth, but stand about, it would
easily cover the whole earth, and soe the same remayne inhabitable:
but one entring amicably into the other, and water moderating the
siccity of the earth, the earth the moisture of that, by their mutuall
comixtion, hereby is the fertility and utility of both Elements conspi
cuous: In like manner the Potter mixeth clay with water, to make
thereof a tractable masse, which hee Shapes by his wheele, and setts in
the warme aire, that it may be gradually dryed; then adds violence of
fire, that his vessells may be well hardened, and condensed into a durable
stone, which can resist both water and fire: Soe allso must wee proceed
in the naturall worke as the Philosophers attest, and therefore doe affirme
that example ought to be taken from the potters. For as to siccity and
moisture, that is, earth and water, wee doubt not that there is much
affinity in both, but much difference in the way of coction, and in the
matter and forme of compounding the Elements: For Potters vessells have
an artificiall forme, the Philosophicall tincture a forme alltogether natu
rall, and soe much more noble than they, by how much the more excel
lent the matter of this is than theirs: either is indeed a worke of earth, but
in the Philosophicall there is nothing sayd to be, which hath not ascended
and attained to the heaven of aire, in that a thicke and faeculent earth is
praedominant: The effect of both is a stone, there a comon, here a Philo
sophicall: by which name a certaine person being seduced put a great
number of artificiall stones or tyles into one chest, and the whiter sort
of flints into another, using Diabolicall conjurations from above, by
which the last were at a certaine time to be converted into silver, the
first into pure gold: but they being supposed to be the Philosophers
Stones, and therefore a great summe of mony accrewing to purchase se
verall things, when the new gold and Silver might be expected, at a
certaine time, in which it not appearing, nor the stones converted into
gold, as was desired, death put an end to the folly and Shame: For gold
or Silver ought not to be expected from that thing, in which it is not na
turally, diabolicall Magicke having noe place in these divine works, but
is as farre different from them, as the author of it from a devout and
pious man, hell from heaven: Soe though it may be esteemed the true
Philosophicall stone, yet let not any man perswade himselfe, that im
possible things can performed by it, us Isaack admonisheth: noe man
being bound either by the lawes of nature, or polity to things im

possible: as for the transmutation of gemms by it, and performing the
malleability of glasse any man thereby perceive, whether these
things are possible, and congrous to this nature, or noe: Geber affirms
that the Philosophers speake many things allegorically, as allso of him
selfe, that where hee spoke clearly and plainly, hee sayd nothing, but
where figuratively, there hee absconded the truth, as wheat under
chaffe: Those things which a man sowes, the same allso will hee reap, which takes
place in vegetables and animalls, though different species may sometimes proceed
from the things sowed: whether these ought to be applyed to metalls,
which are not propagated by seed, as those, must be considered: In these the
parts onely are homogeneous, Sulphur, and Argent vive, in those they are hete
rogeneous or organicke: In these are noe receptacles of seed, but in those:
In these there is not found any nutrition, augmentation, or extension in all
dimensions, in those very much: yea these are elemented weights admitting
mixtion alone, those allso besides mixtion have either a vegetine or sensitive
soule: Neverthelesse it is without doubt true that there is something in places
under the earth, which is not gold now, but will after a thousand years be
gold by nature: Who will deny this to be the analogicall seed of gold? both
gold and the aurificke nature being of one originall and radix, though
this of the more noble forme, and therefore the seed of gold being knowne,
this allso will be manifested: The Philosophers affirme siccity and mois
ture or Sulphur and Argent vive to be that, which being most pure must
